entry.title: Will England become a cashless society?

media:group.media:title: Will England become a cashless society?
media:group.media:description:
Electronic banking, the digital economy, and now coronavirus means an increasingly cashless society. The notes and coins in our pockets are being rapidly replaced by contactless bank cards and mobile phone payments. But not everyone in England is comfortable with the technology.
Al Jazeera’s Paul Brennan reports from Essex, where many want to stick to pounds, shillings and pence.

entry.title: Myanmar: Karen minority demand troops leave area

media:group.media:title: Myanmar: Karen minority demand troops leave area
media:group.media:description:
Myanmar's military says two soldiers accused of killing a woman from an ethnic minority community will face a court-martial. The mother of three's death has reignited anger in Karen state, where there has been unrest for decades. Karen community leaders say the army is using coronavirus lockdown measures as an excuse to attack villagers.
Al Jazeera’s Barbara Angopa reports.

#Myanmar #KarenPeople #AljazeeraEnglish

media:group.media:title: Argentina's pandemic squatters
media:group.media:description:
Argentina's lockdown was due to end on Sunday, but it is being extended because of a surge in cases. The country's economic situation, already in dire straits, has further deteriorated in recent months, and millions are finding it hard to make ends meet. As a result, many have had to leave homes they can no longer afford and squat on land they believe is publicly owned.
Al Jazeera's Teresa Bo reports from Buenos Aires, Argentina.

#Argentina #COVID19 #ArgentinaEconomicalCrisis

entry.title: Young people across the UK worry about their futures

media:group.media:title: Young people across the UK worry about their futures
media:group.media:description:
In the UK, one of the long-term effects of the pandemic will be limiting career prospects for young people. This year is seeing a marked decrease in vacancies and opportunities, and many fear this will persist for years to come.
Al Jazeera’s Sonia Gallego reports from London.

#UKcovid19 #coronavirus #UKeconomy

entry.title: Russia: Thousands protest against Kremlin for fourth week

media:group.media:title: Russia: Thousands protest against Kremlin for fourth week
media:group.media:description:
Mass protests triggered by the arrest of a popular governor in Russia are now in their fourth week. The demonstrations started in the far-eastern city of Khabarovsk, but have spread to the rest of the country.
Al Jazeera’s Emily Siu reports.

entry.title: 'black' to 'Black': Rewriting the race style guide | The Listening Post (Feature)

media:group.media:title: 'black' to 'Black': Rewriting the race style guide | The Listening Post (Feature)
media:group.media:description:
The police killing of George Floyd - a Black man - in Minnesota did more than dominate the news agenda. It filled streets with protests against racism and has started to change things. All kinds of institutions have been affected.
On this front, the American media have a vast range of issues to address, from the lack of diversity in newsrooms to the problems with how Black people are reported on.
What has changed so far? A single letter - the letter "B" - from lowercase to uppercase.
The change sounds small yet it has been a long-standing demand for Black journalists and activists in the United States.
Meenakshi Ravi asks scholars and journalists in the US what the debate is about and what led to this change today.
Contributors
Matthew Hughey - associate professor of sociology, University of Connecticut Lori Tharps - associate professor of journalism, Temple University Erica Britt - sociolinguist and discourse analyst Erin Logan - reporter, LA Times

entry.title: India's political prisoners: UN calls for release of activists

media:group.media:title: India's political prisoners: UN calls for release of activists
media:group.media:description:
The United Nations has joined the calls for the release of human rights activists in India who are in prison awaiting trial under anti-terrorism laws. The conservative BJP government denies accusations by rights groups the charges against the left-wing activists are politically motivated. Many rights groups are asking the government why it has not investigated the alleged role of Hindu nationalists in the violence that Rao and Bharadwaj are in jail for, even though a fact-finding mission found Hindu nationalist leaders were responsible.
Al Jazeera's Elizabeth Puranam reports from New Delhi, India.

#IndiaHumanRights #sudhabharadwaj #varavararao

entry.title: As US jobs recovery falters, virus relief talks stall in Congress

media:group.media:title: As US jobs recovery falters, virus relief talks stall in Congress
media:group.media:description:
About 30 million people have been left unemployed in the United States as the country struggles with the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. But now they could be facing another hardship, as $600-a-week emergency relief payments come to an end.
Al Jazeera's Rob Reynolds reports.

#Coronavirus #UScoronavirus #CoronavirusReliefBill

entry.title: Thousands of Germans protest against coronavirus restrictions

media:group.media:title: Thousands of Germans protest against coronavirus restrictions
media:group.media:description:
Thousands of people have marched in the German capital, unmasked, to protest against virus restrictions that are imposed on the whole country to try to prevent clusters of individual cases from becoming a second wave. Organisers of the protest hoped to bring 500,000 people to Berlin for the protests, but police said only a fraction of that number came. While polls suggest that the majority of Germans support the protective measures in place, protests like this highlight those who do not want to comply with the measures if it inconveniences them.
Dominic Kane reports from Berlin, Germany.

#Germany #Coronavirus #GermanyProtests

entry.title: Thousands demand Netanyahu quit over coronavirus, corruption

media:group.media:title: Thousands demand Netanyahu quit over coronavirus, corruption
media:group.media:description:
Israel is seeing the largest protests in a decade. For the third straight week, thousands gathered outside Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's official residence, demanding he resign. There is frustration over the government's handling of the coronavirus outbreak, as well as the corruption charges Netanyahu faces.
Al Jazeera's Harry Fawcett reports from West Jerusalem.

#Israel #IsraelProtests #Netanyahu

entry.title: Japan coronavirus: Theatre resumes in Tokyo amid surge in cases

media:group.media:title: Japan coronavirus: Theatre resumes in Tokyo amid surge in cases
media:group.media:description:
Japan is facing a resurgence in COVID-19 cases. Tokyo confirmed a record 472 coronavirus infections on Saturday and the capital's governor says a citywide state of emergency may have to be imposed. It is a step that has already been taken in Okinawa. Infections appear to have originated at a US military base. In the midst of the surge in cases, many are welcoming the opening of theatres, but they may not be open for long. Al Jazeera's Laura Burdon-Manley reports.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Japan #COVID19

entry.title: Three men charged in connection with celebrity Twitter hack

media:group.media:title: Three men charged in connection with celebrity Twitter hack
media:group.media:description:
Prosecutors in the United States and the United Kingdom have charged three young men with hacking Twitter. They are accused of taking over the accounts of several high-profile people, including former US President Barack Obama and Tesla boss Elon Musk. Al Jazeera's Sara Khairat reports.

entry.title: Northern England: Restrictions reimposed as COVID-19 cases surge

media:group.media:title: Northern England: Restrictions reimposed as COVID-19 cases surge
media:group.media:description:
Coronavirus restrictions have been reimposed in parts of northern England after an increase in infections. Pubs, restaurants, cafes and gyms remain open, but some people feel being targeted. Al Jazeera's Jonah Hull reports from Oldham, near Manchester.

entry.title: Portugal anti-racism rally: Anger at shooting of Black actor

media:group.media:title: Portugal anti-racism rally: Anger at shooting of Black actor
media:group.media:description:
The killing of a Black actor in Portugal has sparked anti-racism protests. A white man in his 80s has been charged with the murder. Al Jazeera's Barbara Angopa reports.

entry.title: Mexico death toll overtakes UK as third-highest in the world

media:group.media:title: Mexico death toll overtakes UK as third-highest in the world
media:group.media:description:
Mexico has overtaken the United Kingdom as the country with the world's third-highest coronavirus death toll - more than 46,600. On Friday, a multibillion-dollar agreement with the United Nations was announced to buy medical equipment and supplies. Al Jazeera's Manuel Rapalo has more from Mexico City.
